title: AmericasBarometer Labels Guide
text: concise guide demonstrates R users can effectively work AmericasBarometer datasets access variable metadata directly eliminating need external codebooks. features readily visible Stata, often require specific approaches R. guide outlines: multilingual structure storage AmericasBarometer data (including variable labels value labels). implement custom LAPOP Lab functions seamless dataset analysis.

title: AmericasBarometer Labels Guide
text: lapop package contains custom functions analyze data plot figures following LAPOP Lab’s guidelines. LAPOP Lab package already installed machine can install using devtools package : installation successful, need load package library:
code: # Install the LAPOP Lab package: devtools::install_github("https://github.com/lapop-central/lapop",                           force=TRUE,                           build_vignettes = TRUE) library(lapop) # Note: no need for lapop_fonts()  # because we are not plotting figures

what: How LAPOP Lab stores variables metadata
title: AmericasBarometer Labels Guide
text: LAPOP Lab’s AmericasBarometer stores variable labels value labels parallel languages (.e., Spanish/English/Portuguese) directly within dataset structure. allows researchers access metadata without external codebooks : Embedding language-specific labels attributes Stata-formatted files use standardized variable naming conventions maintain consistency across survey waves since 2004. Therefore, Metadata structured facilitate longitudinal analysis. project employs Stata-formatted datasets (.dta) embedded metadata, preserving: Variable labels (.e., question wording). Value labels (.e., responses options). Missing value codes (.e., Applicable, Don’t Know, Refused). result, key advantage LAPOP Lab’s active metadata preservation even distributing data third-party platforms like ICPSR NORC, Stata-formatted metadata remains intact, allowing R/python users still access labels via readstata13 package.

what: How to load AmericasBarometer Data in R
title: AmericasBarometer Labels Guide
text: preferred method loading LAPOP Lab datasets use read.dta13() function readstata13 package. , show key difference recommended approach two alternative methods commonly used researchers: haven::read_dta() rio::import(). R programming language, attributes additional metadata can attached R objects. Attributes provide way store extra information object beyond basic data structure. access attributes object, can use attr() attributes() base functions. methods haven rio packages recover metadata dta files. Thereby, proceed dataset loaded readstata13 package.
code: # READSTATA13 PACKAGE (RECOMMENDED FOR LABELS) data1 <- read.dta13("./BRA 2023 LAPOP AmericasBarometer (v1.0s).dta") names(attributes(data1))  # HAVEN PACKAGE (RECOMMENDED FOR PLOTTING) data2 <- read_dta("./BRA 2023 LAPOP AmericasBarometer (v1.0s).dta") names(attributes(data2))  # RIO PACKAGE (NOT RECOMMENDED) data3 <- import("./BRA 2023 LAPOP AmericasBarometer (v1.0s).dta") names(attributes(data3))

title: AmericasBarometer Labels Guide
text: AmericasBarometer variable labels stored notes Stata .dta files. can find inside “expansion.fields” attribute. varlabels object created nested list (much like JSON object) contain multilingual notes question wording variable. instance, variable ing4 Brazil AB 2023 dataset contain notes question wording lead-English, Spanish, Portuguese.
code: data(bra23)  # Extracting attributes from expasion.fields names(attributes(bra23)) ##  [1] "row.names"        "names"            "datalabel"        "time.stamp"       ##  [5] "formats"          "types"            "val.labels"       "var.labels"       ##  [9] "version"          "label.table"      "expansion.fields" "byteorder"        ## [13] "orig.dim"         "data.label"       "class" varlabels = attr(bra23, "expansion.fields")

what: How do I find the correct language labels?
title: AmericasBarometer Labels Guide
text: important keep mind note numbers may change across countries datasets years depending language survey fielded. Brazil, Brazilian-Portuguese, whereas countries Spanish also English like Jamaica. streamlined approach users want quickly find values notes variable labels without assigning dataset assessing notes directly combination lapply() Filter() functions base R, also compact() map() functions purrr package. approaches extract third element (x[3]) list “expansion.fields” attribute dataset, first element (x[1]) equals “ing4” (.e., variable interest). produce semi-structured list matching third nested elements. ease researchers analysts job, LAPOP Lab developed custom functions deal labels R. First, use lpr_extract_notes transform nested lists expansion.fields attribute long dataframe format contain 3 columns: variable_name, note_id, note_value One can assign variable labels preferred language attributes dataset using another LAPOP Lab function called lpr_set_attr() access data analysis without need accompanying codebook.
code: # Base R approach: # The base R version uses lapply to iterate over the list and returns NULL when  # the condition isn't met, then Filter(Negate(is.null), ...) removes those NULLs. head(   Filter(Negate(is.null), lapply(attr(bra23, "expansion.fields"),    function(x) {     if (x[1] == "ing4") list(note_id = x[2], note_value = x[3])})), n = 3) ## [[1]] ## [[1]]$note_id ## [1] "_lang_l_en" ##  ## [[1]]$note_value ## [1] "ing4_en" ##  ##  ## [[2]] ## [[2]]$note_id ## [1] "_lang_v_en" ##  ## [[2]]$note_value ## [1] "Support for democracy" ##  ##  ## [[3]] ## [[3]]$note_id ## [1] "note0" ##  ## [[3]]$note_value ## [1] "7" # purrr package approach #  The purrr version uses map() to do the same, and also remove NULL results.  tail(   purrr::map_dfr(attr(bra23, "expansion.fields"), ~ {   if (.x[1] == "ing4")      data.frame(       note_id = .x[2],       note_value = .x[3],       stringsAsFactors = FALSE     ) }) ) ##            note_id ## 9  _lang_l_default ## 10 _lang_v_default ## 11           note1 ## 12           note2 ## 13      _lang_v_pt ## 14      _lang_l_pt ##                                                                                                                                                       note_value ## 9                                                                                                                                                     labels2670 ## 10                                                                               ING4. A democracia tem seus problemas, mas é melhor que qualquer outra forma de ## 11 Puede que la democracia tenga problemas, pero es mejor que cualquier otra forma de gobierno. ¿Hasta qué punto está de acuerdo o en desacuerdo con esta frase? ## 12                Democracy may have problems, but it is better than any other form of government.  To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement? ## 13                                                                                                                                            Apoio à democracia ## 14                                                                                                                                                       ing4_pt # Extract AB notes with lpr function BRA23notes <- lpr_extract_notes(bra23) head(BRA23notes, n = 10) # columns names ##    variable_name    note_id                       note_value ## 1         strata _lang_l_en                        strata_en ## 2         strata _lang_v_en                    Survey strata ## 3            q1n _lang_l_en                           q1n_en ## 4            q1n _lang_v_en Gender determined by interviewer ## 5           q1tb _lang_l_en                          q1tb_en ## 6           q1tb _lang_v_en                           Gender ## 7          q1tcb _lang_l_en                         q1tcb_en ## 8          q1tcb _lang_v_en                           Gender ## 9          q1tca _lang_l_en                         q1tca_en ## 10         q1tca _lang_v_en                           Gender table(BRA23notes$note_id) # note information available! ##  ##     _lang_l_default          _lang_l_en          _lang_l_pt     _lang_v_default  ##                 190                1332                1332                 202  ##          _lang_v_en          _lang_v_pt            destring        destring_cmd  ##                1321                1320                   7                   7  ##               note0               note1              note10              note11  ##                 861                 846                   7                   6  ##              note12              note13               note2               note3  ##                   1                   1                 833                 265  ##               note4               note5               note6               note7  ##                 189                 172                 134                  91  ##               note8               note9 spss_variable_label  ##                  68                  25                   3 # English bra23<-lpr_set_attr(bra23, BRA23notes, verbose = F,                     noteid = "note2",                      attribute_name = "qwording_en")  # Spanish bra23<-lpr_set_attr(bra23, BRA23notes, verbose = F,                     noteid = "note1",                      attribute_name = "qwording_es")  # Portuguese bra23<-lpr_set_attr(bra23, BRA23notes, verbose = F,                     noteid = "note3",                      attribute_name = "qwording_pt")   # Printing languages attr(bra23$ing4, "qwording_en") # English ## [1] "Democracy may have problems, but it is better than any other form of government.  To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?" attr(bra23$ing4, "qwording_es") # Spanish ## [1] "Puede que la democracia tenga problemas, pero es mejor que cualquier otra forma de gobierno. ¿Hasta qué punto está de acuerdo o en desacuerdo con esta frase?" attr(bra23$ing4, "qwording_pt") # Portuguese ## [1] "A democracia tem seus problemas, mas é melhor que qualquer outra forma de governo. Até que ponto concorda ou discorda desta frase?"

title: AmericasBarometer Labels Guide
text: AmericasBarometer values labels (.e., response options) differently variable labels stored inside “label.table” attribute. extract use another LAPOP Lab custom function called lpr_format_labels set response options attribute across languages. Default language English default attribute name roslabel function allows custom attribute names shown :
code: bra23 <- lpr_set_ros(bra23) # Default English  bra23 <- lpr_set_ros(bra23, lang_id = "es",                       attribute_name = "respuestas") # Spanish  bra23 <- lpr_set_ros(bra23, lang_id = "pt",                       attribute_name = "ROsLabels_pt") # Portuguese  # Printing ROs attr(bra23$ing4, "roslabel") # English ## [1] "Response Options: (1) Strongly disagree (7) Strongly agree" attr(bra23$ing4, "respuestas") # Spanish ## [1] "Opciones de Respuesta: (1) Muy en desacuerdo (7) Muy de acuerdo" attr(bra23$ing4, "ROsLabels_pt") # Portuguese ## [1] "Alternativas de Resposta: (1) Discorda muito (7) Concorda muito"

text: lapop package brings two datasets already design effects (weighted).
code: library(lapop) # Single-country Single-year AmericasBarometer 2023 Brazil data(bra23)  # AmericasBarometer 2006-2023 Brazil Merge data(cm23)  # AmericasBarometer 2023 Year Merge data(ym23)

title: LAPOP Visualization Guide
text: AmericasBarometer use weight1500 comparative datasets time country, wt weights country specific datasets (single-country single-year). AmericasBarometer primary sampling units (ids = upm) stratification variable (strata = strata) account survey’s complex design. Finally, PSUs nested within strata, properly reflecting survey’s hierarchical sampling structure. lpr_data() function apply survey design effects.
code: # Single-Country Single-Year bra23w <- lpr_data(bra23, wt = TRUE)  print(bra23w) ## Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) ## With (125) clusters. ## Called via srvyr ## Sampling variables: ##   - ids: upm  ##   - strata: strata  ##   - weights: wt  ## Data variables:  ##   - ing4 (int), b13 (int), b21 (int), b31 (int), b12 (int), fs2 (fct), idio2 ##     (fct), wealth (int), wave (fct), pais (fct), year (fct), upm (int), strata ##     (dbl), wt (dbl), pais_lab (chr) # Single-Country Multi-Year cm23w <- lpr_data(cm23)  print(cm23w) ## Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) ## With (3943) clusters. ## Called via srvyr ## Sampling variables: ##   - ids: upm  ##   - strata: strata  ##   - weights: weight1500  ## Data variables:  ##   - ing4 (int), b13 (int), b21 (int), b31 (int), wave (fct), pais (fct), year ##     (fct), upm (int), strata (dbl), weight1500 (dbl), pais_lab (chr) # Multi-Country Single-Year ym23w <- lpr_data(ym23)  print(ym23w) ## Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) ## With (7856) clusters. ## Called via srvyr ## Sampling variables: ##   - ids: upm  ##   - strata: strata  ##   - weights: weight1500  ## Data variables:  ##   - b12 (dbl+lbl), b18 (dbl+lbl), wave (dbl+lbl), pais (dbl+lbl), year ##     (dbl+lbl), ing4 (dbl+lbl), pn4 (dbl+lbl), vb21n (dbl+lbl), q14f (dbl+lbl), ##     edre (dbl+lbl), wealth (dbl), q1tc_r (dbl+lbl), upm (dbl+lbl), strata ##     (dbl), weight1500 (dbl), pais_lab (chr)

what: Fonts for 2023 Pulse of Democracy report.
title: LAPOP Visualization Guide
text: Running lapop_fonts() start analysis ensures exported charts polished, standardized appearance ensure consistent professional typography LAPOP plots. function loads Nunito Roboto fonts.
code: lapop_fonts() # Load fonts

title: LAPOP Visualization Guide
code: fig1.1_data <- lpr_ts(cm23w, outcome = "ing4", rec = c(5, 7), use_wave = TRUE)  lapop_ts(fig1.1_data,          ymin = 50,          ymax = 80,          main_title = "Support for democracy decline a decade ago and remains comparatively low in Brazil",          subtitle = "% who support democracy")

title: LAPOP Visualization Guide
code: fig1.2_data <- lpr_cc(ym23w, outcome = "ing4", rec = c(5, 7))  lapop_cc(fig1.2_data,          main_title = "In many countries, only about one in two adults support democracy",          subtitle = "% who support democracy")

title: LAPOP Visualization Guide
code: fig2.1_data <- lpr_mline(cm23w,                          outcome = c("b13", "b21", "b31"),                          rec = c(5, 7), rec2 = c(5, 7), rec3 = c(5, 7))  # Changing legend for readibility fig2.1_data$varlabel <- ifelse(fig2.1_data$varlabel == "b13", "National Legislature",                            ifelse(fig2.1_data$varlabel=="b21", "Political Parties",                                  "Supreme Court"))  lapop_mline(fig2.1_data,             main_title = "Trust in executives has declined to a level similar to other political institutions",             subtitle = "% who trust...")

title: LAPOP Visualization Guide
code: fig2.3_data <- lpr_ccm(ym23w,                        outcome_vars = c("b12", "b18"),                        rec1 = c(5, 7),                        rec2 = c(5, 7))  # Changing legend for readibility fig2.3_data$var <- ifelse(fig2.3_data$var == "b12", "Armed Forces", "National Police")  lapop_ccm(fig2.3_data,           main_title = "The public typically reports more trust in the armed forces than the police, but levels vary",           subtitle = "% who trust...")

what: Figure Mover Example: Satisfaction with Democracy
title: LAPOP Visualization Guide
code: library(dplyr)  ym23w$variables <- ym23w$variables %>%     mutate(     edrer = as.numeric(edre),     gender = as.numeric(q1tc_r)   ) %>%   mutate(edrer = case_when(     edrer <= 2 ~ "None/Primary",     edrer %in% c(3, 4) ~ "Secondary",     edrer > 4 ~ "Superior",     TRUE ~ NA_character_   ),    edrer = factor(edrer, levels = c("None/Primary", "Secondary", "Superior")),   gender = ifelse(q1tc_r == 3, NA, q1tc_r)) %>%   mutate(gender = case_when(     gender == 1 ~ "Men",     gender == 2 ~ "Women",      TRUE ~ NA_character_   ))  # Changing legend for readibility  attributes(ym23w$variables$gender)$label <- "Gender" attributes(ym23w$variables$edrer)$label <- "Education" attributes(ym23w$variables$wealth)$label <- "Wealth"  fig_mover <- lpr_mover(ym23w,                        outcome = "pn4",                        grouping_vars = c("gender", "edrer", "wealth"),                        rec = c(1, 2))   lapop_mover(fig_mover,             main_title = "Satisfaction with democracy is significantly lower among women, those with higher educational attainment, and the middle class",             subtitle = "% who are satisfied with democracy")

title: LAPOP Cross-Country Bar Graphs — lapop_cc
text: function creates bar graphs comparing values across countries using LAPOP formatting.

title: LAPOP Cross-Country Bar Graphs — lapop_cc
code: lapop_cc(   data,   outcome_var = data$prop,   lower_bound = data$lb,   vallabel = data$vallabel,   upper_bound = data$ub,   label_var = data$proplabel,   ymin = 0,   ymax = 100,   lang = "en",   highlight = "",   main_title = "",   source_info = "LAPOP",   subtitle = "",   sort = "",   color_scheme = "#784885",   label_size = 5,   max_countries = 30,   label_angle = 0 )

title: LAPOP Cross-Country Bar Graphs — lapop_cc
text: data Data Frame. Dataset used analysis.  data frame columns titled vallabel (values x-axis variable (e.g. pais); character vector), prop (outcome variable; numeric), proplabel (text outcome variable; character), lb (lower bound estimate; numeric), ub (upper bound estimate; numeric). Default: None (must supplied). vallabel, outcome_var, label_var, lower_bound, upper_bound Character, numeric, character, numeric, numeric. component plot data can manually specified case default columns data frame used (, example, values given variable altered stored new column). x ymin, ymax Numeric.  Minimum maximum values y-axis. Default: 0 100. lang Character.  Changes default subtitle text source info either Spanish English. translate input text, main title variable labels.  Takes either "en" (English) "es" (Spanish).  Default: "en". highlight Character.  Country interest.  highlight (make darker) country's bar. Input must match entry "vallabel" exactly. Default: None. main_title Character.  Title graph.  Default: None. source_info Character.  Information dataset used (country, years, version, etc.), added bottom-left corner graph. Default: LAPOP ("Source: LAPOP Lab" printed). subtitle Character.  Describes values/data shown graph, e.g., "percentage Mexicans say...)". Default: None. sort Character. Method sorting bars.  Options: "hi-lo" (highest lowest y value), "lo-hi" (lowest highest), "alpha" (alphabetical vallabel/x-axis label). Default: Order data frame. color_scheme Character.  Color bars.  Takes hex number, beginning "#". Default: #784885. label_size Numeric.  Size text data labels (percentages bars).  Default: 5. max_countries Numeric. Threshold automatic x-axis label rotation. number unique country labels exceeds value, labels rotated better readability. Default: 20. label_angle Numeric. code: lapop_stack(   data,   outcome_var = data$prop,   prop_labels = data$proplabel,   var_labels = data$varlabel,   value_labels = data$vallabel,   xvar = NULL,   lang = "en",   main_title = "",   subtitle = "",   source_info = "LAPOP",   rev_values = FALSE,   rev_variables = FALSE,   hide_small_values = TRUE,   order_bars = FALSE,   subtitle_h_just = 0,   fixed_aspect_ratio = TRUE,   legendnrow = 1,   color_scheme = c("#2D708E", "#008381", "#C74E49", "#784885", "#a43d6a", "#202020") )

title: LAPOP Stacked Bar Graphs — lapop_stack
text: data Data Frame. Dataset used analysis.  data frame columns titled varlabel (name(s)/label(s) variable(s) interest; character), vallabel (names/labels values variable; character), prop (outcome variable value; numeric), proplabel (text outcome variable value; character). Default: None (must provided). outcome_var, prop_labels, var_labels, value_labels Numeric, character, character, character. component data plotted can manually specified case default columns data frame used (, example, values given variable altered stored new column). xvar Character. Column name group plots . match column name dataset. Default: NULL (grouping). lang Character.  Changes default subtitle text source info either Spanish English. translate input text, main title variable labels.  Takes either "en" (English) "es" (Spanish).  Default: "en". main_title Character.  Title graph.  Default: None. subtitle Character.  Describes values/data shown graph, e.g., "Percent support...". Default: None. source_info Character.  Information dataset used (country, years, version, etc.), added end "Source: " bottom-left corner graph. Default: LAPOP ("Source: LAPOP Lab" printed). rev_values Logical.  order values variable reversed?  Default: FALSE. rev_variables Logical.  order variables reversed?  Default: FALSE. hide_small_values Logical.  labels categories less 5 percent hidden?  Default: TRUE. order_bars Logical.  categories placed descending order bar?  Default: FALSE. showing distributions multiple categorical variables. subtitle_h_just Numeric.  Move subtitle/legend text left (negative numbers) right (positive numbers). Ranges -100 100.  Default: 0. fixed_aspect_ratio Logical.  aspect ratio set specific value (0.35)? prevents bars stretching vertically fit plot area.  Set false large number bars (> 10).  Default: TRUE. legendnrow Numeric.  many rows legend labels. Default: 1. color_scheme Character.  Color data bars value.  Allows 6 values. Takes hex numbers, beginning "#". Default: c("#2D708E", "#008381", "#C74E49", "#784885", "#a43d6a","#202020") (navy blue, turquoise, teal, green, sap green, pea soup).

title: LAPOP Time-Series Graphs — lapop_ts
text: data Data Frame. Dataset used analysis.  data frame columns titled wave (survey wave/year; character vector), prop (outcome variable; numeric), proplabel (text outcome variable; character); lb (lower bound estimate; numeric), ub (upper bound estimate; numeric). Default: None (must supplied). wave_var, outcome_var, label_var, lower_bound, upper_bound, point_var Character, numeric, character, numeric, numeric, character. component data plotted can manually specified case default columns data frame used (, example, values given variable altered stored new column). ymin, ymax Numeric.  Minimum maximum values y-axis. Default: 0, 100. main_title Character.  Title graph.  Default: None. source_info Character.  Information dataset used (country, years, version, etc.), added bottom-left corner graph. Default: LAPOP ("Source: LAPOP Lab" printed). subtitle Character.  Describes values/data shown graph, e.g., "Percent Mexicans agree...". Default: None. lang Character.  Changes default subtitle text source info either Spanish English. translate input text, main title variable labels.  #' Takes either "en" (English) "es" (Spanish).  Default: "en". color_scheme Character.  Color lines dots.  Takes hex number, beginning "#". Default: "#A43D6A" (red). percentages Logical.  outcome variable percentage?  Set FALSE using means raw values, y-axis adjusts accordingly. Default: TRUE. label_vjust Numeric. Customize vertical space points labels. Default: -2.1. max_years Numeric. Threshold automatic x-axis label rotation. number unique country labels exceeds value, labels smaller necessary rotated better readability. Default: 15 years. label_angle Numeric. Angle (degrees) rotate x-axis labels max_years exceeded. Default: 0.

title: LAPOP Cross-Country Bar Graph Pre-Processing — lpr_cc
text: data survey object.  data analyzed. outcome Outcome variable(s) interest plotted across countries. can handle single variable across countries, multiple variables instead multiple countries. See examples . xvar Grouping variable. Default: pais_lab. can handle variables grouping like year/wave. rec Numeric. minimum maximum values outcome variable included numerator percentage.  example, variable 1-7 scale rec c(5, 7), function show percentage chose answer 5, 6, 7 valid answers.  Default: c(1, 1). rec2 Numeric. rec(). Default: c(1, 1). rec3 Numeric. rec(). Default: c(1, 1). rec4 Numeric. rec(). Default: c(1, 1). ci_level Numeric. Confidence interval level estimates.  Default: 0.95 mean Logical.  TRUE, produce mean variable rather rescaling percentage.  Default: FALSE. filesave Character.  Path file name save dataframe csv. cfmt changes format numbers displayed bars. Uses sprintf string formatting syntax. Default whole numbers percentages tenths place means. sort Character. value bars sorted: x y. Options "y" (default; value outcome variable), "xv" (underlying values x variable), "xl" (labels x variable, .e., alphabetical). order Character.  bars sorted.  Options "hi-lo" (default) "lo-hi". ttest Logical.  TRUE, conduct pairwise t-tests difference means individual x levels save attr(x, "t_test_results"). Default: FALSE. keep_nr Logical.  TRUE, convert "know" (missing code .) "response" (missing code .b) valid data (value = 99) use denominator calculating percentages.  default examine valid responses .  Default: FALSE.

TRUE, produce mean variable rather rescaling percentage.  Default: FALSE. filesave Character.  Path file name save dataframe csv. cfmt Character. Changes format numbers displayed bars. Uses sprintf string formatting syntax. Default whole numbers percentages tenths place means. sort Character. value bars sorted. Options "y" (default; value first outcome variable), "xv" (underlying values x variable), "xl" (labels x variable, .e., alphabetical). order Character.  bars sorted.  Options "hi-lo" (default) "lo-hi". ttest Logical.  TRUE, conduct pairwise t-tests difference means outcomes vs. x-vars save attr(x, "t_test_results"). Default: FALSE. keep_nr Logical.  TRUE, convert "know" (missing code .) "response" (missing code .b) valid data (value = 99) use denominator calculating percentages.  default examine valid responses .  Default: FALSE.

code: lpr_coef(   outcome = NULL,   xvar = NULL,   interact = NULL,   model = "linear",   data = NULL,   estimate = c("coef"),   vlabs = NULL,   omit = NULL,   filesave = NULL,   replace = FALSE,   level = 95 )

title: LAPOP Regression Coefficients Graph Pre-Processing — lpr_coef
text: outcome Dependent variable svyglm regression model. (e.g., "outcome_name"). one variable allowed. xvar Vector independent variables svyglm regression model (e.g., "xvar1+xvar2+xvar3" ). Multiple variables allowed. interact Interaction terms (e.g., "xvar1`*`xvar2 + xvar3`:`xvar4"). Supports `:` `*` operators interacting variables. Optional, default NULL. model Model family object glm. Default gaussian regression (.e., "linear"). logit model, use model="binomial" data Survey design data lpr_data() output. estimate Character. Graph either coefficients (.e., `coef`) change probabilities (.e., `contrast`). Default "coef." vlabs Character. Rename variable labels displayed graph produced lapop_coef(). instance, vlabs=c("old_varname" = "new_varname"). omit Character. display coefficients independent variables. Default display variables included model. omit variables need include raw "varname" omit argument. filesave Character. Path file name csv extension save dataframe output. replace Logical. Replace dataset output already exists. Default FALSE. level Numeric. Set confidence level numeric values; default 95 percent.

text: data survey object.  data analyzed. outcome Outcome variable(s) interest plotted across countries waves, supplied character string vector strings. xvar Character. grouping variable plotted along x-axis (technically, vertical axis lapop_dumb). Usually country (pais). Default: "pais". Numeric. vector values "wave" specify two waves included plot. rec Numeric. minimum maximum values outcome variable included numerator percentage.  example, variable 1-7 scale rec c(5, 7), function show percentage chose answer 5, 6, 7 valid answers.  Can also supply one value , produce percentage chose value values. Default: c(1, 1). ci_level Numeric. Confidence interval level estimates.  Default: 0.95 mean Logical.  TRUE, produce mean variable rather recoding percentage.  Default: FALSE. filesave Character.  Path file name save dataframe csv. cfmt Character. Changes format numbers displayed bars. Uses sprintf string formatting syntax. Default whole numbers percentages tenths place means. sort Character. value bars sorted. Options "prop1" (value outcome variable wave 1), "prop2" (default; value outcome variable wave 2), "xv" (underlying values x variable), "xl" (labels x variable, .e., alphabetical), "diff" (difference outcome two waves). order Character.  bars sorted.  Options "hi-lo" (default) "lo-hi". ttest Logical.  TRUE, conduct pairwise t-tests difference means pais-wave combinations save attr(x, "t_test_results"). Default: FALSE. keep_nr Logical.  TRUE, convert "know" (missing code .) "response" (missing code .b) valid data (value = 99) use denominator calculating percentages.  default examine valid responses .  Default: FALSE.

title: LAPOP Rescale — lpr_resc
text: function allows users rescale reorder variables.  designed variables class "labelled" rescaling work numeric factor variables .

title: LAPOP Rescale — lpr_resc
code: lpr_resc(   var,   min = 0L,   max = 1L,   reverse = FALSE,   only_reverse = FALSE,   only_flip = FALSE,   map = FALSE,   new_varlabel = NULL,   new_vallabels = NULL )

title: LAPOP Rescale — lpr_resc
text: var Vector (class "labelled" "haven_labelled").  original variable rescale. min Integer. Minimum value new rescaled variables; default 0. max Integer. Maximum value new rescaled variables; default 1. reverse Logical.  Reverse code variable rescaling. Default: FALSE. only_reverse Logical.  Reverse code variable, rescale. Default: FALSE. only_flip Logical. Flip variable coding.  Unlike "only_reverse", exactly preserve values old variable.  example, variable codes 1, 2, 3, 5, 10, only_flip code values 10, 5, 3, 2, 1 (instead 10, 9, 8, 6, 1).  Generally, reverse preferred preserve underlying scale.  compatible rescale. Default: FALSE. map Logical. TRUE, print cross-tab showing old variable new, recoded variable.  Used verify new variable coded correctly. Default: FALSE. new_varlabel Character.  Variable label new variable. Default: old variable's label. new_vallabels Character vector. Supply custom names value labels. Default: value labels old variable.

title: LAPOP Rescale — lpr_resc
text: input variable rescaled

title: Set Variable Attributes from AmericasBarometer Notes (with propagation) — lpr_set_attr

title: Set Variable Attributes from AmericasBarometer Notes (with propagation) — lpr_set_attr
code: lpr_set_attr(   data,   notes,   noteid = character(),   attribute_name = character(),   verbose = FALSE,   propagate = TRUE,   overwrite = TRUE )

title: Set Variable Attributes from AmericasBarometer Notes (with propagation) — lpr_set_attr
text: data data.frame variables annotate notes data.frame columns variable_name, note_id, note_value noteid character scalar; note_id use (e.g., "qtext_en") attribute_name character scalar; attribute name set (e.g., "qwording_en") verbose logical; TRUE prints variables notes available found data propagate logical; TRUE, also set <varname>_* children. Useful nominal variables multiple response options variables. Default TRUE. overwrite logical; FALSE, overwrite existing attribute variable. Default TRUE.

what: Set Response Option (ROS) labels for variables in AmericasBarometer datasets — lpr_set_ros
title: Set Response Option (ROS) labels for variables in AmericasBarometer datasets — lpr_set_ros
text: function extracts formatted response option labels AmericasBarometer variables, using label tables stored attributes. labels formatted corresponding numeric codes can pulled multiple languages.

title: Set Response Option (ROS) labels for variables in AmericasBarometer datasets — lpr_set_ros
code: lpr_set_ros(data, lang_id = "en", attribute_name = "roslabel")

title: Set Response Option (ROS) labels for variables in AmericasBarometer datasets — lpr_set_ros
text: data data frame loaded using readstata13 containing label.table attributes. lang_id Language identifier labels ("en" English, "es" Spanish, "pt" Portuguese). Default "en" (English). attribute_name name attribute formatted response options string stored. Default "roslabel".

title: Set Response Option (ROS) labels for variables in AmericasBarometer datasets — lpr_set_ros
text: input data frame response option labels added variables attributes

title: Set Response Option (ROS) labels for variables in AmericasBarometer datasets — lpr_set_ros
text: function looks label tables stored attributes data frame, names following pattern "VARNAME_lang_id" (e.g., "ing4_en" English labels variable ing4). label table named numeric vector names response labels values corresponding codes. Special codes (values >= 1000) excluded response options string.

title: Set Response Option (ROS) labels for variables in AmericasBarometer datasets — lpr_set_ros
code: require(lapop); data(bra23)  # Apply the function bra23 <- lpr_set_ros(bra23) # Default English bra23 <- lpr_set_ros(bra23, lang_id = "es", attribute_name = "respuestas") # Spanish bra23 <- lpr_set_ros(bra23, lang_id = "pt", attribute_name = "ROsLabels_pt") # Portuguese  # View the resulting attribute attr(bra23$ing4, "roslabel") #> [1] "Response Options: (1) Strongly disagree (7) Strongly agree" attr(bra23$ing4, "respuestas") #> [1] "Opciones de Respuesta: (1) Muy en desacuerdo (7) Muy de acuerdo" attr(bra23$ing4, "ROsLabels_pt") #> [1] "Alternativas de Resposta: (1) Discorda muito (7) Concorda muito"

title: LAPOP Stacked Bar Graph Pre-Processing — lpr_stack
text: data data analyzed. requires survey object lpr_data() function. outcome Vector variables plotted. xvar Character. Outcome variable broken variable. Default NULL sort Character. value bars sorted: x y. Options "y" (default; value outcome variable), "xv" (underlying values x variable), "xl" (labels x variable, .e., alphabetical). order Character. bars sorted. Options "hi-lo" (default) "lo-hi". filesave Character. Path file name save dataframe csv. keep_nr Logical. TRUE, convert "know" (missing code .) "response" (missing code .b) valid data (value = 99) use denominator calculating percentages.  default examine valid responses .  Default: FALSE.

what: LAPOP Time-Series Line Graph Pre-Processing — lpr_ts
title: LAPOP Time-Series Line Graph Pre-Processing — lpr_ts
text: function creates dataframes can input lapop_ts comparing values across time line graph using LAPOP formatting.

title: LAPOP Time-Series Line Graph Pre-Processing — lpr_ts
code: lpr_ts(   data,   outcome,   rec = c(1, 1),   use_wave = FALSE,   ci_level = 0.95,   mean = FALSE,   filesave = "",   cfmt = "",   ttest = FALSE,   keep_nr = FALSE )

title: LAPOP Time-Series Line Graph Pre-Processing — lpr_ts
text: data survey object.  data analyzed. outcome Character.  Outcome variable interest plotted across time. rec Numeric. minimum maximum values outcome variable included numerator percentage.  example, variable 1-7 scale rec c(5, 7), function show percentage chose answer 5, 6, 7 valid answers.  Can also supply one value , produce percentage chose value values. Default: c(1, 1). use_wave Logical.  TRUE, use "wave" x-axis; otherwise, use "year".  Default: FALSE. ci_level Numeric. Confidence interval level estimates.  Default: 0.95 mean Logical.  TRUE, produce mean variable rather rescaling percentage.  Default: FALSE. filesave Character.  Path file name save dataframe csv. cfmt Character. changes format numbers displayed bars. Uses sprintf string formatting syntax. Default whole numbers percentages tenths place means. ttest Logical.  TRUE, conduct pairwise t-tests difference means individual x levels save attr(x, "t_test_results"). Default: FALSE. keep_nr Logical.  TRUE, convert "know" (missing code .) "response" (missing code .b) valid data (value = 99) use denominator calculating percentages.  default examine valid responses .  Default: FALSE.
